sen.j: 志賀 直哉（しが なおや、明治16年（1883年）2月20日 - 昭和46年（1971年）10月21日）は、日本の小説家。
sen.e: Naoya SHIGA (February 20, 1883-October 21, 1971) was a Japanese novelist.
Naoya SHIGA (February 20, 1883-October 21, 1971) was a Japanese novelist.
Naoya SHIGA (February 20, 1883-October 21, 1971) was a Japanese novelist.

sen.j: 宮城県石巻市生まれ。
sen.e: He was born in Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture.
He was born in Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture.
He was born in Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture.

sen.j: 白樺派を代表する小説家のひとり。
sen.e: He was one of the representative novelists of Shirakaba school.
He was one of the leading novelists of the Shirakaba school.
sen.cmt: Leading sounds more natural than "representative", the literal translation.
sen.e: He was one of the leading novelists of the Shirakaba school.

sen.j: 代表作は『暗夜行路』、『和解 (小説)』、『小僧の神様』、『城の崎にて』。
sen.e: His representative works are "A Dark Night's Passing," "Reconciliation (A Novel)," "The Shopboy's God," and "At Cape Kinosaki."
His best known works are "A Dark Night's Passing," "Reconciliation (Novel)," "The Shopboy's God," and "At Cape Kinosaki."
His best known works are "A Dark Night's Passing," "Reconciliation (Novel)," "The Shopboy's God," and "At Cape Kinosaki."

sen.j: 志賀直哉の祖父・直道は、旧相馬中村藩主相馬氏の家令を勤め、古河財閥創始者古河市兵衛と共に足尾銅山の開発をし、相馬事件にも係わった。
sen.e: Naoya SHIGA's grandfather, Naomichi SHIGA, served the head of Soma Clan of the former Soma- nakamura Domain as a butler and together with Ichibe FURUKAWA, the founder of Furukawa Zaibatsu, developed Ashio Copper Mine and was involved in Soma Incident.

Naoya SHIGA's grandfather, Naomichi SHIGA, served the Soma Clan of the former Soma- Nakamura Domain as a butler; he developed Ashio Copper Mine together with Ichibe FURUKAWA, the founder of Furukawa Zaibatsu, and was involved in the Soma Incident.

Naoya SHIGA's grandfather, Naomichi SHIGA, served as a butler of the Soma Clan, the lord of the former Soma- Nakamura Domain; he developed Ashio Copper Mine together with Ichibe FURUKAWA, the founder of Furukawa Zaibatsu, and was involved in the Soma Incident.
sen.cmt: 藩主を加えたため語順を多少変更しました。

sen.j: 父直温は総武鉄道や帝国生命保険の取締役を経て、明治期の財界で重きをなした人物。
sen.e: His father, Naoharu SHIGA, became an important figure in the financial world of the Meiji period through serving as the director of Sobu Railway and Teikoku Life Insurance.
His father, Naoharu SHIGA, became an important figure in the Meiji period financial world through serving as the director of Sobu Railway and Teikoku Life Insurance.
His father, Naoharu SHIGA, became an important figure in the Meiji period financial world through serving as the director of Sobu Railway and Teikoku Life Insurance.

sen.j: 第一銀行石巻支店に勤務していた父・直温の任地､宮城県石巻市に生まれ、3歳より上京し祖父母のもと東京で育てられた。
sen.e: He was born in Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture where his father, Naoharu, worked for and had the post at the First Bank's Ishinomaki Branch; he came to Tokyo when he was three and was raised by his grandparents.
Naoya was born in Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture, where his father Naoharu worked at the First Bank's Ishinomaki Branch; he came to Tokyo when he was three and was raised by his grandparents.
Naoya was born in Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture, where his father Naoharu worked at the First Bank's Ishinomaki Branch; he came to Tokyo when he was three and was raised by his grandparents.

sen.j: 学習院初等科、中等科、学習院高等科 (旧制)を経て、東京大学英文科入学。
sen.e: He graduated from Gakushuin Primary School, Gakushuin Junior High School and Gakushuin High School (of the old system); then he enrolled at the University of Tokyo Department of English literature.

He graduated from Gakushuin Primary School, Gakushuin Junior High School and Gakushuin High School (of the old system), after which he enrolled in the Department of English Literature at the University of Tokyo.
sen.cmt: I am not sure why this sentence has a semicolon. (Word order)
sen.e: He graduated from Gakushuin Primary School, Gakushuin Junior High School and Gakushuin High School (of the old system), after which he enrolled in the Department of English Literature at the University of Tokyo.

sen.j: 1908年ごろ、7年間師事した内村鑑三の下を去り、キリスト教から離れる。
sen.e: He left Kanzo UCHIMURA under whom he studied for 7 years and parted from Christianity around 1908.
Around 1908, he left Kanzo UCHIMURA, under whom he had studied for 7 years, and parted with Christianity.
Around 1908, he left Kanzo UCHIMURA, under whom he had studied for 7 years, and parted with Christianity.

sen.j: 国文科に転じた後に大学を中退した。
sen.e: He dropped out of the university after changing his major to Japanese literature.
He dropped out of university after changing his major to Japanese literature.
He dropped out of university after changing his major to Japanese literature.

sen.j: 1910年に学習院時代からの友人武者小路実篤らと、文芸雑誌『白樺 (雑誌)』を創刊した。
sen.e: He published the first issue of "Shirakaba (Magazine)," the literary mgazine, together with Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, his friend from Gakushuin days, in 1910.
In 1910, he published the first issue of the literary magazine"Shirakaba,"together with Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, his friend from Gakushuin.
sen.cmt: I think it is redundant to have magazine in brackets and then state it was a literary magazine. I also changed sentence order a bit.
sen.e: In 1910, he published the first issue of the literary magazine "Shirakaba," together with Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, his friend from Gakushuin.
sen.cmt: スペースを修正しました。

sen.j: このころ、元々作家となること反対していた父との対立が結婚問題などにより、さらに深まったため家を出る。
sen.e: Around this time, he left home because his conflict with his father who opposed him becoming a novelist from the outset worsened over the issues of his marriage etc.
Around this time, he left home because his conflict with his father, who had always been opposed to his becoming a novelist, worsened over his marriage and other issues.
Around this time, he left home because his conflict with his father, who had always been opposed to his becoming a novelist, worsened over his marriage and other issues.

sen.j: 1917年には和解した。
sen.e: He reconciled with his father in 1917.
He reconciled with his father in 1917.
He reconciled with his father in 1917.

sen.j: 同じ年に『城の崎にて』『和解』を発表。
sen.e: He published "At Cape Kinosaki" and "Reconciliation" in the same year.
He published "At Cape Kinosaki" and "Reconciliation" in the same year.
He published "At Cape Kinosaki" and "Reconciliation" in the same year.

sen.j: その後も『小僧の神様』、『焚火』などの名作を生んだ。
sen.e: Afterward he wrote masterpiece such as "The Shopboy's God" and "Bonfire."
Afterward, he wrote masterpieces such as "The Shopboy's God" and "Bonfire."
Afterward, he wrote masterpieces such as "The Shopboy's God" and "Bonfire."

sen.j: 推敲を尽くした簡潔な文体は、「無駄のない文章」として、大正から昭和にかけて多くの文学者に大きな影響を及ぼし、小説の神様とも称された。
sen.e: His minimalistic style as a result of many revisions was admired as "Concise Writing" and had a significant influence on subsequent generations of writers from the Taisho Era to the Showa Era; he was known as a "god of novel."

His minimalistic style, the result of many revisions, was admired as "concise writing", and significantly influenced subsequent generations of writers from the Taisho Era to the Showa Era; he was known as the "god of novels."

His minimalistic style, the result of many revisions, was admired as 'concise writing,' and significantly influenced subsequent generations of writers from the Taisho Era to the Showa Era; he was known as the "god of novels."
sen.cmt: コンマの位置を変更しました。クォーテーションをシングルにしました。

sen.j: 著者唯一の長編小説である『暗夜行路』（1921年 - 1937年）は近代日本文学の代表作の一つに挙げられ、小説家・大岡昇平は近代文学の最高峰であると讃えている。
sen.e: The author's only novel, "A Dark Night's Passing" (1921-1937), is considered as one of the most important works of Modern Japanese Literature; Shohei OOKA, a novelist, praised it as the highest achievement of modern literature.

The author's only full-length novel, "A Dark Night's Passing" (1921-1937), is considered one of the most important works of Modern Japanese Literature; Shohei OOKA, a novelist, praised it as the highest achievement of modern literature.

The author's only full-length novel, "A Dark Night's Passing" (1921-1937), is considered one of the most important works of Modern Japanese Literature; Shohei OOKA, a novelist, praised it as the highest achievement of modern literature.

sen.j: 生涯26回の転居をしている。
sen.e: He moved his residence 26 times in his life.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He changed residences 26 times in his life.
He changed residences 26 times in his life.

sen.j: 戦前は千葉県我孫子市、京都市、奈良市などに住まい、美術に造詣を深め、美術図録『座右宝』を自ら編集し刊行した。
sen.e: Before the war, he lived in the places like Abiko City, Chiba Prefecture, Kyoto City, Nara City, and deepened his knowledge of art; he edited and published, an art catalog, "Zayu-hou (Timeless Treasures)."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Before the war, he lived in places like Abiko City, Chiba Prefecture, Kyoto City, and Nara City, where he deepened his knowledge of art and edited and published an art catalog, "Zayu-hou (Timeless Treasures)."

Before the war, he lived in places like Abiko City, Chiba Prefecture, Kyoto City, and Nara City, where he deepened his knowledge of art and edited and published an art catalog, "Zayu-hou (Timeless Treasures)."

sen.j: 1938年東京に居を戻したものの、戦後の一時期、熱海大洞台に移住、『山鳩』『朝顔』などの小品を発表した。
sen.e: He moved his residence back to Tokyo in 1938; however, he relocated to Oboradai, Atami at one point after the war and published short stories, "Turtledove" and "Morning Glories."
He moved back to Tokyo in 1938, but relocated to Oboradai, Atami for a period of time after the war and published short stories such as "Turtledove" and "Morning Glories."
He moved back to Tokyo in 1938, but relocated to Oboradai, Atami for a period of time after the war and published short stories such as "Turtledove" and "Morning Glories."

sen.j: 生涯を通じて極めて寡作であった。
sen.e: Throughout his life, he published very few stories.
Throughout his life, he published very few stories.
Throughout his life, he published very few stories.

sen.j: 志賀直哉が今もなお強烈な影響を与えるのは、視覚的把握の正確さである。
sen.e: The accuracy of a visual description in Naoya SHIGA's writing still has a strong influence on many writers today.
Naoya SHIGA's accuracy of visual description still exerts a powerful influence today.
sen.cmt: Word choice, word order (subject of the influence was not mentioned in original sentence, so I omitted it)
sen.e: Naoya SHIGA's accuracy of visual description still exerts a powerful influence today.

sen.j: 透明感のある文章のポイントは、徹底した写実。
sen.e: The characteristic of his writing with exceptional clarity is thorough realism.
One characteristic of his exceptionally clear writing is thorough realism.
One characteristic of his exceptionally clear writing is thorough realism.

sen.j: その点をよく受けとめ、評価したのが小林秀雄であることは言うまでもない。
sen.e: Needless to say, the strongest supporter of him was Hideo KOBAYASHI who understood and appreciated this characteristic well.
Needless to say, Hideo KOBAYASHI, who well understood and appreciated this characteristic, was his strongest supporter.
Needless to say, Hideo KOBAYASHI, who well understood and appreciated this characteristic, was his strongest supporter.

sen.j: 志賀直哉の後半生は、1949年、親交を深めていた谷崎潤一郎と共に文化勲章受章。
sen.e: Naoya SHIGA and Junichiro TANIZAKI who he was forging a friendship with were awarded Bunka Kunsho (Order of Culture) together in the latter half of his life.
In the latter half of his life, Naoya SHIGA was awarded a Bunka Kunsho (Order of Culture) together with Junichiro TANIZAKI, with whom he'd forged a friendship.
sen.cmt: Word choice, word order, grammar, punctuation
sen.e: In the latter half of his life, Naoya SHIGA was awarded a Bunka Kunsho (Order of Culture) in 1949 together with Junichiro TANIZAKI, with whom he'd forged a friendship.

sen.j: 交友関係では、学習院以来の武者小路実篤、細川護立、柳宗悦らの他、梅原龍三郎、安倍能成、広津和郎、安井曽太郎、谷川徹三ら、限定されつつも一流の文化人と交流があった。
sen.e: His circle of friends included Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI who had been his friend since Gakushuin days, Moritatsu HOSOKAWA, Muneyoshi YANAGI, and others, as well as Ryuzaburo UMEHARA, Yoshishige ABE, Kazuo HIROTSU, Sotaro YASUI, Tetsuzo TANIKAWA; he socialized with exclusive but highly-cultured people who were considered the best in his days.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: His circle of friends was limited, but composed of highly-cultured people of the first order; these included Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, who had been his friend since Gakushuin days, Moritatsu HOSOKAWA, Muneyoshi YANAGI, and others, as well as Ryuzaburo UMEHARA, Yoshishige ABE, Kazuo HIROTSU, Sotaro YASUI, and Tetsuzo TANIKAWA.
sen.cmt: Grammar, word order, word choice, punctuation
sen.e: His circle of friends was limited, but composed of highly-cultured people of the first order; these included Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, who had been his friend since Gakushuin days, Moritatsu HOSOKAWA, Muneyoshi YANAGI, and others, as well as Ryuzaburo UMEHARA, Yoshishige ABE, Kazuo HIROTSU, Sotaro YASUI, and Tetsuzo TANIKAWA.

sen.j: その様子は、残された多くの日誌、書簡にみることができる。
sen.e: The account of his life at the time was recorded in many of his archived letters and diaries.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The state of his life at the time may be seen in the many letters and diaries he left.
The state of his life at the time may be seen in the many letters and diaries he left.

sen.j: 晩年は渋谷常盤松に居を移し、1971年88歳で肺炎と衰弱のため没した。
sen.e: He moved his residence to Tokiwamatsu, Shibuya Ward, in his later years; he died of pneumonia and debilitation at the age of 88 in 1971.
In his later years, he moved to Tokiwamatsu, Shibuya Ward; he died of pneumonia and debilitation in 1971, at the age of 88.
In his later years, he moved to Tokiwamatsu, Shibuya Ward; he died of pneumonia and debilitation in 1971, at the age of 88.

sen.j: 没後、多くの原稿類は日本近代文学館に寄贈された。
sen.e: Many of his manuscript and the like were donated to the Museum of Modern Japanese Literature after his death.
After his death, many of his manuscripts and papers were donated to the Museum of Modern Japanese Literature.
After his death, many of his manuscripts and papers were donated to the Museum of Modern Japanese Literature.

sen.j: 岩波書店から『志賀直哉全集』が数次出版されている。
sen.e: "The Complete Works of Naoya SHIGA" were published in multiple volumes by Iwanami Shoten, Publishers.
"The Complete Works of Naoya SHIGA" is published in multiple volumes by Iwanami Shoten.
"The Complete Works of Naoya SHIGA" is published in multiple volumes by Iwanami Shoten.

sen.j: 彼に師事する作家として、瀧井孝作、尾崎一雄、小林秀雄 (批評家)、網野菊、藤枝静男、島村利正、直井潔、阿川弘之、小林多喜二らがいる。
sen.e: The novelists who studied under him were Kousaku TAKII, Kazuo OZAKI, Hideo KOBAYASHI (critic), Kiku AMINO, Shizuo FUJIEDA, Toshimasa SHIMAMURA, Kiyoshi NAOI, Hiroyuki AGAWA, and Takiji KOBAYASHI.
Novelists who studied under him include Kousaku TAKII, Kazuo OZAKI, Hideo KOBAYASHI (critic), Kiku AMINO, Shizuo FUJIEDA, Toshimasa SHIMAMURA, Kiyoshi NAOI, Hiroyuki AGAWA, and Takiji KOBAYASHI.
Novelists who studied under him include Kousaku TAKII, Kazuo OZAKI, Hideo KOBAYASHI (critic), Kiku AMINO, Shizuo FUJIEDA, Toshimasa SHIMAMURA, Kiyoshi NAOI, Hiroyuki AGAWA, and Takiji KOBAYASHI.

sen.j: 白樺文学館（千葉県我孫子市）は、志賀の原稿、書簡、ゆかりの品を公開している。
sen.e: Shirakaba Literary Museum (Abiko City, Chiba Prefecture) exhibits the manuscript, the letters, and items associated with him.
Shirakaba Literary Museum (Abiko City, Chiba Prefecture) exhibits manuscripts, letters, and items associated with Shiga.
Shirakaba Literary Museum (Abiko City, Chiba Prefecture) exhibits manuscripts, letters, and items associated with Shiga.

tit.e: Chronological List of the Main Events

sen.j: 1883年（明治16年）、2月20日に陸前石巻（現在の石巻市住吉町）に、銀行員の父直温（なおはる）、母銀の次男として志賀直哉生まれる。
sen.e: Naoya Shiga was born in Rikuzen-ishinomaki (present-day Sumiyoshi-cho, Ishinomaki City) on February 20, 1883 as the second son to a father, Naoharu, who was a banker and a mother, Gin.
Naoya Shiga was born on February 20, 1883 in Rikuzen-ishinomaki (present-day Sumiyoshi-cho, Ishinomaki City) as the second son of his father, Naoharu (a bank employee), and his mother, Gin.
Naoya Shiga was born on February 20, 1883 in Rikuzen-ishinomaki (present-day Sumiyoshi-cho, Ishinomaki City) as the second son of his father, Naoharu (a bank employee), and his mother, Gin.

sen.j: 祖父直道は旧相馬中村藩士で、二宮尊徳の門人。
sen.e: His grandfather, Naomichi, was a feudal retainer of Soma-nakamura domain and a disciple of Sontoku NINOMIYA.
His grandfather, Naomichi, had been a feudal retainer of the Soma-Nakamura domain and a disciple of Sontoku NINOMIYA.
His grandfather, Naomichi, had been a feudal retainer of the Soma-Nakamura domain and a disciple of Sontoku NINOMIYA.

sen.j: 1889年（明治22年）、学習院の初等科へ入学。
sen.e: He enrolled at Gakushuin Primary School in 1889.
He enrolled at Gakushuin Primary School in 1889.
He enrolled at Gakushuin Primary School in 1889.

sen.j: 1895年（明治28年）、学習院の中等科へ進学。
sen.e: He continued on and enrolled at Gakushuin Junior High School in 1895.
He advanced to Gakushuin Junior High School, enrolling in 1895.
sen.cmt: Grammar, punctuation, word order, word choice
sen.e: He advanced to Gakushuin Junior High School, enrolling in 1895.

sen.j: 1901年（明治34年）、足尾銅山鉱毒事件の見解について、父と衝突。
sen.e: He disputed with his father over the view of Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident in 1901.
In 1901, he and his father clashed over their views of the Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident.
In 1901, he and his father clashed over their views of the Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident.

sen.j: 以後の決定的な不和のキッカケとなる。
sen.e: The dispute started the undeniable conflict between SHIGA and his father.
The dispute triggered the decisive conflict between SHIGA and his father.
The dispute triggered the decisive conflict between SHIGA and his father.

sen.j: （志賀が足尾鉱毒事件の見学会に参加しようとしたところ、祖父がかつて古河市兵衛と足尾銅山を共同経営していたという理由から父に反対された）
sen.e: SHIGA wanted to participate in the tour of Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident; however, his father opposed him because SHIGA's grandfather used to run Ashio Copper Mine jointly with Ichibe FURUKAWA.

(SHIGA wanted to participate in the excursion tour of the Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident; however, his father opposed it because SHIGA's grandfather used to run the Ashio Copper Mine jointly with Ichibe FURUKAWA.)

(SHIGA wanted to participate in the excursion tour of the Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident; however, his father opposed it because SHIGA's grandfather used to run the Ashio Copper Mine jointly with Ichibe FURUKAWA.)

sen.j: 1906年（明治39年）、東京大学へ入学。
sen.e: He enrolled at The University of Tokyo in 1906.
He enrolled at The University of Tokyo in 1906.
He enrolled at The University of Tokyo in 1906.

sen.j: 1907年（明治40年）、父と結婚についての問題で再度衝突。
sen.e: He disputed again with his father over the issue of his marriage in 1907.
He and his father clashed again in 1907, over the issue of his marriage.
He and his father clashed again in 1907, over the issue of his marriage.

sen.j: 1908年（明治41年）、処女作となる『或る朝』を発表。
sen.e: He published "One Morning," his first work, in 1908.
He published "One Morning," his first work, in 1908.
He published "One Morning," his first work, in 1908.

sen.j: 回覧雑誌『望野』を創刊。
sen.e: He published the first issue of "Boya (Perspective)," circular magazine.
He published the first issue of "Boya (Perspective)," a circular magazine.
He published the first issue of "Boya (Perspective)," a circular magazine.

sen.j: 1910年（明治43年）、『白樺』を創刊。
sen.e: He published the first issue of "Shirakaba" in 1910.
He published the first issue of "Shirakaba" in 1910.
He published the first issue of "Shirakaba" in 1910.

sen.j: 『網走まで』を発表。
sen.e: He published "As Far as Abashiri."
He published "As Far as Abashiri."
He published "As Far as Abashiri."

sen.j: 東京帝国大学を中退。
sen.e: He dropped out of the University of Tokyo.
sen.cmt: 東京帝国大学→東京大学に統一しました。
sen.e: He dropped out of the University of Tokyo.
He dropped out of the University of Tokyo.

sen.j: 徴兵検査を受け甲種合格。
sen.e: He took the examination for conscription and passed it for class A.
He took the conscription exam and passed it for Class A.
He took the conscription exam and passed it for Class A.

sen.j: 市川の砲兵連隊に入営するが、8日後に除隊。
sen.e: He joined the artilleryman regiment in Ichikawa; however, he was discharged eight days later.
He joined the artillery regiment in Ichikawa, but was discharged eight days later.
He joined the artillery regiment in Ichikawa, but was discharged eight days later.

sen.j: 1912年（大正元年）、『大津順吉』『正義派』を発表。
sen.e: He published "Otsu Junkichi" and "A Righteous Man" in 1912.
He published "Otsu Junkichi" and "A Righteous Man" in 1912.
He published "Otsu Junkichi" and "A Righteous Man" in 1912.

sen.j: 10月、父との不和が原因で、東京を離れ広島県尾道市に渡る。
sen.e: He moved away from Tokyo and relocated to Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture, because of his conflict with his father in October.
In October, he moved away from Tokyo because of the conflict with his father, relocating to Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture.
sen.cmt: "In October" lends itself to misinterpretation at the end of sentence. (Word order, punctuation)
sen.e: In October, he moved away from Tokyo because of the conflict with his father, relocating to Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture.

sen.j: 1913年（大正2年）、『清兵衛と瓢箪』『范の犯罪』を発表。
sen.e: He published "Seibei and His Gourds" and "Han's Crime" 1913.
He published "Seibei and His Gourds" and "Han's Crime" in 1913.
He published "Seibei and His Gourds" and "Han's Crime" in 1913.
sen.cmt: スペースを詰めました。

sen.j: 1914年（大正3年）、勘解由小路康子（武者小路実篤の従妹にあたる）と婚約。
sen.e: He was engaged to Yasuko KADENOKOJI, Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI's cousin, in 1914.
He got engaged to Yasuko KADENOKOJI, Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI's cousin, in 1914.
He got engaged to Yasuko KADENOKOJI, Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI's cousin, in 1914.

sen.j: 1915年（大正4年）、柳宗悦にすすめられて我孫子に移住。
sen.e: He relocated to Abiko City recommended by Muneyoshi YANAGI in 1915.
In 1915, at the recommendation of Muneyoshi YANAGI, he moved to Abiko City.
In 1915, at the recommendation of Muneyoshi YANAGI, he moved to Abiko City.

sen.j: 1917年（大正6年）、『城ノ崎にて』『和解 (小説)』を発表。
sen.e: He published "At Cape Kinosaki" and "Reconciliation (A Novel)" in 1917.
He published "At Cape Kinosaki" and "Reconciliation (A Novel)" in 1917.
He published "At Cape Kinosaki" and "Reconciliation (A Novel)" in 1917.

sen.j: 父との不和が解消される。
sen.e: He reconciled with his father.
He reconciled with his father.
He reconciled with his father.

sen.j: 1920年（大正9年）、『小僧の神様』『焚火』を発表。
sen.e: He published "The Shopboy's God " and "Bonfire" in 1920.
He published "The Shopboy's God " and "Bonfire" in 1920.
He published "The Shopboy's God " and "Bonfire" in 1920.

sen.j: 1921年（大正10年）、『暗夜行路』の前編のみを発表。
sen.e: He published the first half of the two-part novel, "A Dark Night's Passing," in 1921.
He published the first half of the two-part novel, "A Dark Night's Passing," in 1921.
He published the first half of the two-part novel, "A Dark Night's Passing," in 1921.

sen.j: 1931年（昭和6年）、11月訪ねて来た小林多喜二を宿泊させ懇談。
sen.e: He asked Takiji KOBAYASHI who came to visit to stay over and had talks with him in November, 1931.
In November of 1931, Takiji KOBAYASHI came to visit, and he let him stay and chatted with him.
In November of 1931, Takiji KOBAYASHI came to visit, and he let him stay and chatted with him.

sen.j: 1933年（昭和8年）、『万暦赤絵』を発表。
sen.e: He published "Banreki akae (Chinaware)" in 1933.
He published "Banreki Akae" (Chinaware) in 1933.
He published "Banreki Akae" (Chinaware) in 1933.

sen.j: 1937年（昭和12年）、『暗夜行路』の後編を発表し、完結させる。
sen.e: He published the second half of "A Dark Night's Passing" and completed it in 1937.
In 1937, he published the second half of "A Dark Night's Passing", completing it.
In 1937, he published the second half of "A Dark Night's Passing," completing it.
sen.cmt: コンマの位置を変更しました。

sen.j: 1949年（昭和24年）、文化勲章を受章。
sen.e: He was awarded Bunka Kunsho in 1949.
He was awarded the Order of Culture in 1949.
He was awarded the Order of Culture in 1949.
He died on October 21, 1971.
He died on October 21, 1971.
He died on October 21, 1971.

sen.j: 現在奈良県奈良市高畑町に旧邸宅が「志賀直哉旧居 (奈良市高畑)」として保存されており見学を行うことができる。
sen.e: Today, his old residence is preserved as "SHIGA Naoya Kyukyo (the former residence of Naoya SHIGA)" in Takahata-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture and open to the public for viewing.
Today, his old residence in Takahata-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture is preserved as "SHIGA Naoya Kyukyo (the former residence of Naoya SHIGA)", and is open for public viewing.
Today, his old residence in Takahata-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture is preserved as 'SHIGA Naoya Kyukyo (the former residence of Naoya SHIGA),' and is open for public viewing.
sen.cmt: コンマの位置を変更しました。クォーテーションをシングルにしました。

sen.j: 1925年に京都市山科区から奈良市幸町に引っ越してきた志賀は、奈良公園に隣接し若草山の眺望も良い高畑に居宅を1929年に建設した。
sen.e: SHIGA moved to Saiwai-cho, Nara City from Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City, in 1925 and build a residence in Takahata which was adjacent to Nara Park and with the excellent view of Mt. Mt. Wakakusa in 1929.
In 1925, SHIGA moved to Saiwai-cho, Nara City from Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City; in 1929, he built a residence in Takahata which was adjacent to Nara Park and had an excellent view of Mt. Wakakusa.
sen.cmt: Grammar, word order, word choice, punctuation
sen.e: In 1925, SHIGA moved to Saiwai-cho, Nara City from Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City; in 1929, he built a residence in Takahata which was adjacent to Nara Park and had an excellent view of Mt. Wakakusa.

sen.j: この際設自ら設計に携わり、1938年から鎌倉市に移り住むまでの10年間を家族と共にこの家で過ごした。
sen.e: He was involved in the design of the residence and lived there with his family for 10 years until he moved to Kamakura City in 1983.
He was involved in the design of the residence and lived there with his family for 10 years before moving to Kamakura City in 1983.
He was involved in the design of the residence and lived there with his family for 10 years before moving to Kamakura City in 1983.

sen.j: 数寄屋造りに加え洋風や中国風の様式も取り入れており、洋風サンルームや娯楽室、書斎、茶室、食堂を備えたモダンかつ合理的な建物であった。
sen.e: The residence which was modern and functional with a western style sunroom, an entertainment room, a library, a tea room, and a dining hall was built in the style of a tea-ceremony house; however it incorporated other architectural styles such as European and Chinese as well.

The residence was built in the style of a tea-ceremony house, but incorporated European and Chinese architectural styles as well; it was modern and functional, with a western style sunroom, an entertainment room, a library, a tea room, and a dining hall.
sen.cmt: Grammar, word order, word choice, punctuation
sen.e: The residence was built in the style of a tea-ceremony house, but incorporated European and Chinese architectural styles as well; it was modern and functional, with a western style sunroom, an entertainment room, a library, a tea room, and a dining hall.

sen.j: 志賀はここで「暗夜行路」のほか「痴情」、「プラトニック・ラブ」、「邦子」などの作品を執筆した。
sen.e: He wrote his masterpiece "A Dark Night's Passing," as well as "Infatuation," "Platonic Love," and "Kuniko" in this residence.
SHIGA wrote his masterpiece "A Dark Night's Passing" at this residence, as well as "Infatuation," "Platonic Love," and "Kuniko".
sen.cmt: Grammar, word order, word choice, punctuation
sen.e: SHIGA wrote his masterpiece "A Dark Night's Passing" at this residence, as well as "Infatuation," "Platonic Love," and "Kuniko".

sen.j: 志賀を慕って武者小路実篤や小林秀雄 (批評家)、尾崎一雄、若山為三、小川晴暘、入江泰吉、亀井勝一郎、小林多喜二、桑原武夫ら白樺派の文人や画家・文化人がしばしば訪れ、文学論や芸術論などを語り合う一大文化サロンとなり、いつしか高畑サロンと呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: The writers, painters, and other people of culture such as Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, Hideo KOBAYASHI (critic), Kazuo OZAKI, Tamezou WAKAYAMA, Seiyou OGAWA, Taikichi IRIE, Katsuichiro KAMEI, Takiji KOBAYASHI, and Takeo KUWABARA, who admired SHIGA frequently visited his residence which became a major cultural salon where people met and discussed art and literature; eventually, his residence came to be known as the Takahata Salon.

Writers, painters, and other people of culture who admired Shiga, such as Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, Hideo KOBAYASHI (critic), Kazuo OZAKI, Tamezou WAKAYAMA, Seiyou OGAWA, Taikichi IRIE, Katsuichiro KAMEI, Takiji KOBAYASHI, and Takeo KUWABARA, frequently visited his residence; it became a major cultural salon where people met and discussed art and literature, and eventually came to be known as the Takahata Salon.

Writers of the Shirakaba school, painters, and other people of culture who admired Shiga, such as Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI, Hideo KOBAYASHI (critic), Kazuo OZAKI, Tamezou WAKAYAMA, Seiyo OGAWA, Taikichi IRIE, Katsuichiro KAMEI, Takiji KOBAYASHI, and Takeo KUWABARA, frequently visited his residence; it became a major cultural salon where people met and discussed art and literature, and eventually came to be known as the Takahata Salon.
sen.cmt: 名前の表記を変更しました。白樺派の訳抜けを追加しました。

sen.j: 書斎や2階の客間からは若草山や三蓋山、高円山の眺めが美しく、庭園も執筆に疲れた時に散策できるように作られていた。
sen.e: The library and a guest room from the second floor had a beautiful view of Mt. Wakakusa and Mt. Takamado; the garden was designed for taking a stroll when he was tired from writing.
The library and second-floor guest room had beautiful views of Mt. Wakakusa and Mt. Takamado; the garden was designed so that he could take a stroll when he was tired from writing.
The library and second-floor guest room had beautiful views of Mt. Wakakusa and Mt. Takamado; the garden was designed so that he could take a stroll when he was tired from writing.

sen.j: 生前、東大寺別当の上司海雲とは特に親しく長い付き合いをしていた。
sen.e: He had a long and close relationship with Kaiun KAMITSUKASA, Betto (the head priest) of Todai-ji Temple, in his life.
While alive, he had a long and close relationship with Kaiun KAMITSUKASA, Betto (the head priest) of Todai-ji Temple.
While alive, he had a long and close relationship with Kaiun KAMITSUKASA, Betto (the head priest) of Todai-ji Temple.

sen.j: 奈良を去り東京へ帰った後も次のように奈良への愛着を表している。
sen.e: He expressed his affection for Nara as below even after he had left there and came back to Tokyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He expressed his affection for Nara, as shown below, even after he had left it and returned to Tokyo.
He expressed his affection for Nara, as shown below, even after he had left it and returned to Tokyo.

sen.j: 「奈良はいい所だが、男の児を育てるには何か物足りぬものを感じ、東京へ引っ越してきたが、私自身には未練があり、今でも小さな家でも建てて、もう一度住んでみたい気がしている」
sen.e: He said, "Nara was a great place but I was raising a boy and I thought that it was not challenging enough for my son. So we moved to Tokyo. But I have lingering affection toward Nara and I often think that I would love to build a small house and live there again even today."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He said, "Nara was a great place, but I was raising a boy and felt it wasn't quite the place for such a task, so we moved to Tokyo; that said, I have a lingering affection for Nara, and even today I often think that I would love to build a small house and live there again."

He said, "Nara was a great place, but I was raising a boy and felt it wasn't quite the place for such a task, so we moved to Tokyo; that said, I have a lingering affection for Nara, and even today I often think that I would love to build a small house and live there again."

sen.j: 志賀のサロンの一部は上司海雲に引き継がれていった。
sen.e: Kaiun KAMITSUKASA took over a part of SHIGA's salon.
Kaiun KAMITSUKASA took over a portion of SHIGA's salon.
Kaiun KAMITSUKASA took over a portion of SHIGA's salon.

tit.cmt: public estimationは文学の評価にそぐわないと思います。

sen.j: 白樺派の作家であるが、作品には自然主義の影響も指摘される。
sen.e: He was a Shirakaba School's novelist but some critics pointed out that his work also shows an influence of naturalism.
Although he was a novelist of the Shirakaba school, some critics have pointed out that his work also shows the influence of naturalism.
Although he was a novelist of the Shirakaba school, some critics have pointed out that his work also shows the influence of naturalism.

sen.j: 無駄のない文章は小説の文体のひとつの理想と見なされ評価が高い。
sen.e: His concise writing is seen as one form of the ideal writing styles and highly regarded.
His concise writing is seen as one type of ideal literary style, and is regarded highly.
His concise writing is seen as one type of ideal literary style, and is regarded highly.

sen.j: そのため作品は文章修業のための模写の題材にされることもある。
sen.e: Therefore, his work is sometimes chosen for the model for imitating in order to study writing.
Therefore, his work is sometimes chosen as a model to imitate in order to study writing.
Therefore, his work is sometimes chosen as a model to imitate in order to study writing.

sen.j: 芥川龍之介は、志賀の小説を高く評価し自分の創作上の理想と呼んだ。
sen.e: Ryunosuke AKUTAGAWA regarded SHIGA's novel highly and called it the ideal of his own creative writing.
Ryunosuke AKUTAGAWA thought highly of SHIGA's novels, calling them the ideal he aspired to in his own creative writing.
Ryunosuke AKUTAGAWA thought highly of SHIGA's novels, calling them the ideal he aspired to in his own creative writing.

sen.j: 当時の文学青年から崇拝され、代表作「小僧の神様」にかけて「比喩としての「神様」「神」一覧」に擬せられていたが、太宰治から長篇小説『津軽』の中で批判を受けて立腹し、座談会の席上で太宰を激しく攻撃した。
sen.e: He was worshipped by the literary youth at the time and was called a "god of novel" after his representative work "The Shopboy's God"; however, he was offended by DAZAI's criticism of him found in DAZAI's full length novel "Tsugaru" and attacked DAZAI viciously at the round-table discussion.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「比喩としての「神様」「神」一覧」がわかりにくいのですが、「代表作にちなんで、小説の神様と呼ばれていた」としました。
sen.e: He was worshipped by the literary youth of the time and was called a "god of novels" after his representative work, "The Shopboy's God"; however, he was offended by Osamu DAZAI's criticism of him in DAZAI's full-length novel "Tsugaru", and attacked him viciously at a round-table discussion.
sen.cmt: Word choice, word order, punctuation, inserted name
sen.e: He was worshipped by the literary youth of the time and was called a "god of novels" after his representative work, "The Shopboy's God"; however, he was offended by Osamu DAZAI's criticism of him in DAZAI's full-length novel "Tsugaru," and attacked him viciously at a round-table discussion.
sen.cmt: コンマの位置を変更しました。

sen.j: これに対して太宰も連載評論「如是我聞」を書いて志賀に反撃したことがある。
sen.e: In response to SHIGA's attack, DAZAI counterattacked by writing "Myozegamon," a serialized critical essay.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: DAZAI fought back against SHIGA's attack by writing "Myozegamon," a serialized critical essay.
DAZAI fought back against SHIGA's attack by writing "Myozegamon," a serialized critical essay.

sen.j: 小林多喜二は志賀直哉に心酔しており、作品の評を乞うたこともある。
sen.e: Takiji KOBAYASHI adored Naoya SHIGA and asked SHIGA's opinion of his work.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Takiji KOBAYASHI adored Naoya SHIGA and asked for SHIGA's opinion of his work.
Takiji KOBAYASHI adored Naoya SHIGA and asked for SHIGA's opinion of his work.

sen.j: しかし、多くのプロレタリア文学作家が共産党の強い影響下にあることを指摘して「主人持ちの文学」と評し、プロレタリア文学の党派性を批判した。
sen.e: However, SHIGA criticized the partisanship of the proletarian literature pointing out that many writers of the proletarian literature were under a strong influence of the communist party and described the proletarian literature as "The Literature Waiting for the Leader."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, SHIGA criticized the partisanship of the proletarian literature, pointing out that many writers of proletarian literature were strongly influenced by the communist party, and described proletarian literature as "literature with a master."

However, SHIGA criticized the partisanship of the proletarian literature, pointing out that many writers of proletarian literature were strongly influenced by the communist party, and described proletarian literature as "literature with a master."

sen.j: その後、小林没後の1935年のインタビューでは、人をうつ力があれば主人持ちでもかまわないという趣旨の発言をしている（聞き手は貴司山治）。
sen.e: Later, he retracted his remark somewhat in the interview after Kobayashi's death in 1935; in effect, he offered the comment that as long as writing can touch people's hearts, it still can wait for the leader (Yamaji KISHI was the interviewer).

He later retracted his remark somewhat in a 1935 interview after Kobayashi's death; in effect, he offered the comment that as long as a work touches people's hearts, it doesn't matter whether it has a master or not (Yamaji KISHI was the interviewer).

He later retracted his remark somewhat in a 1935 interview after Kobayashi's death; in effect, he offered the comment that as long as a work touches people's hearts, it doesn't matter whether it has a master or not (Yamaji KISHI was the interviewer).

sen.j: また、戦後一時期新日本文学会の賛助会員として名を連ねたが、中野重治が発表した文章に不快感をおぼえ、賛助会員を辞退したということもあった。
sen.e: He lent his name to The New Japanese Literature Society as a supporting member for a period of time after the war; however, he objected to the writing of Shigeharu NAKANO and resigned his position as a supporting member.

He lent his name to The New Japanese Literature Society as a supporting member for a period of time after the war; however, he objected to the writing of Shigeharu NAKANO and resigned his position as a supporting member.

He lent his name to The New Japanese Literature Society as a supporting member for a period of time after the war; however, he objected to the writing of Shigeharu NAKANO and resigned his position as a supporting member.

sen.j: 戦時中は短文「シンガポール陥落」等を発表して当時の軍国主義的風潮に流される傾向にあったにもかかわらず、敗戦後は掌を返したように変節。
sen.e: He published a short essay "The Fall of Singapore" etc. during the war and tended to go along with the militaristic trend of the time; however, he changed his attitude completely and turned to the other direction after the defeat in the war.
He published short essays ("The Fall of Singapore" and others) during the war, and tended to follow the militaristic trend of the time; however, after the defeat, he changed his attitude completely.
He published short essays ("The Fall of Singapore" and others) during the war, and tended to follow the militaristic trend of the time; however, after the defeat, he changed his attitude completely.

sen.j: 日本語を廃止してフランス語を公用語にすべしと説いたこともしばしば批判されている。
sen.e: He was criticized for advocating the abolishment of Japanese and adoption of French as an official language.
He was criticized for advocating the abolishment of Japanese and adoption of French as the official language.
He was criticized for advocating the abolishment of Japanese and adoption of French as the official language.

sen.j: 批判者の代表として丸谷才一を挙げることができる。
sen.e: Saiichi MARUYA was one of the ardent critics of SHIGA.
Saiichi MARUYA was one of SHIGA's ardent critics.
Saiichi MARUYA was one of SHIGA's ardent critics.

sen.j: これに対して蓮實重彦は『反日本語論』や『表層批評宣言』などの中で志賀を擁護した。
sen.e: On the contrary, Shigehiko HASUMI protected SHIGA in his writing, "Han nihongo ron (Against Japanese Language)" and "Hyoso hihyo sengen (The Critique of Surface Layer)."
In contrast, Shigehiko HASUMI defended SHIGA in his writing, "Han nihongo ron (Against the Japanese Language)" and "Hyoso hihyo sengen (A Critique of the Surface Layer)."
In contrast, Shigehiko HASUMI defended SHIGA in his writing, "Han nihongo ron (Against the Japanese Language)" and "Hyoso hihyo sengen (A Critique of the Surface Layer)."
